awd_titl_txt: Hybrid Deterministic-Stochastic Methodology for Simulating Spatial Evolution in Large Populations
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to develop new computational methods to study the growth and spread of initially small mutant populations that drive biological phenomena like spread of antibiotic resistance or development of treatment resistant tumors.   One notoriously difficult problem in evolutionary simulations is the coexistence of very large and very small populations. This is a common occurrence, because random mutations give rise to relatively small clones, which could play an important role in evolution. For example, these small clones could at some later time harbor further mutations that lead to the formation of a 'super-mutant,' which eventually takes over the population. It is the simulation of such scenarios that presents serious computational problems, because the larger the overall population, the slower the computational process. In many realistic scenarios, further complications arise from spatial constraints. Examples include solid tumors and biofilms--bacterial communities with complex spatial structures, implicated both in public health and in industry. To illustrate application of the computational techniques, the optimization of melanoma (skin cancer) treatment will be studied in the presence of resistant mutants that have developed 'addiction' to the drug. Mathematics can guide how the on/off periods of therapy need to be timed to contain resistance. Similar considerations apply to antibiotic-resistant bacteria. Complementing the research will be efforts to introduce under-represented minority high-school students to the process of scientific inquiry through a summer school, with the opportunity to work on projects in computational biology. 

At the center of enhancing computational speed is the development of a versatile technique capable of efficiently simulating large heterogeneous stochastic populations. Spatial agent-based models of cellular growth will be considered that are common to a wide variety of ecological and evolutionary modeling endeavors. They take into account the processes of cell division and death, as well as mutations and spatial interactions. Deterministic (PDE) approximations of such spatial, stochastic processes generally do not yield accurate time series. In this project, first, deterministic representations of the agent-based models will be constructed by deriving the stochastic master equation of the agent-based model and using the moment closure techniques. This step will provide a fundamental correction to equations based on mean-field behavior. Then, a spatial hybrid stochastic-deterministic algorithm will be developed. The main problem is the 'stiffness' of typical evolutionary systems, resulting from the existence of small, fluctuating populations that can be essential to the final outcome. In traditional methods, this leads to a dramatic decrease of the step size for large populations. Here, a solution to this problem is proposed, by dynamically partitioning the population into small and large subpopulations, with the assumptions that large subpopulations are well described by deterministic laws and are decoupled from the influence of small subpopulations, while the stochasticity of small subpopulations is preserved (and the large populations still affect their dynamics). These approaches will enable simulation of evolutionary processes in large, multi-component, spatially structured evolutionary processes at manageable speeds.

por.por_cntn:
The major goal of this project was to develop computational methodologies to study evolutionary dynamics in spatially structured, large populations, and to gain insights into the evolutionary dynamics in spatially structured populations.

When studying the evolution of cancer cells or bacteria, realistic scenarios involve large populations and low mutation rates. The problem is that while the total population size can be very large, mutant sub-populations can exist at relatively low levels, which requires stochastic simulations (that is, simulations that allow randomness, and where different outcomes are observed in repeated trials).  Stochastic simulations quickly become computationally very expensive when large population sizes are involved. Often, simplifying assumptions are made to run computer simulations in a feasible amount of time, such as assuming smaller populations and larger mutation rates. For well-mixed populations, stochastic-deterministic hybrid methodologies have been developed to simulate the dynamics of small mutant populations stochastically, while simultaneously simulating the larger populations deterministically. This significantly speeds up the computation time and allows for more realistic simulations. Such methodologies, however, have been lacking for spatially structured populations. Many, if not most, populations in nature are spatially structured. The lack of a corresponding hybrid methodology therefore represented a barrier to computationally study evolutionary dynamics in large spatially structured populations under realistic assumptions. To get around this limitation, we devised a numerical stochastic-deterministic hybrid methodology that can describe spatial mutant evolution for large population sizes in a computationally efficient way. This methodology has been validated against fully stochastic models in select settings, and provides a new tool to construct biologically realistic computational models of mutant evolution in systems such as biofilms, cancer, or viral populations. This methodology results in a significant acceleration in computational time, making large-scale simulations a lot more feasible.

 

The newly generated methodology was applied to a variety of specific biological scenarios. One application was evolution of tumor cells, which is a major factor in carcinogenesis, and also in the emergence of drug resistant mutants. Another interesting application concerned evolution in viral infections. In particular, we applied our methodology to study the role of multiple infection and intracellular interactions among different virus strains. These interactions include so-called complementation, when an inferior virus strain (.e.g. defective virus) is helped by a more competent one, and interference, when a virus strain can actively inhibit another. In these systems, multiple infection of cells introduces further complexity: besides the presence of small mutant sub-populations, multiply infected cells can represent additional small subpopulations that behave in a random fashion and require stochastic simulations. We extended our methodology to cover this setting, which allows a more thorough investigation of viral evolutionary dynamics in the context of multiple infection of cells. Human immunodeficiency virus infection was a particular focus in this respect.      

 

Work completed within this project has broader impacts on other fields, including virology, oncology, and epidemiology, because the methodology developed, and insights obtained through the usage of the methodology, can be extended to numerous applications within those disciplines. Beyond the scientific explorations, the results of this research have been incorporated into the material of graduate and undergraduate courses at UC Irvine, which are taught to both mathematics and public health students. Furthermore, funds and activities connected to this project were used to promote diversity, inclusion and equity. For example, funds were used to generate innovative K-12 educational materials, in which complex biological topics were explained with the help of dance choreography and narration. This was recorded in a series of short videos, which were distributed to K-12 schools in Orange County, CA, and beyond. Inclusivity and equity were further promoted at the university level, for example through many DEI-related activities, in which both faculty and students connected to this project played central roles.
